body_content.explanation:
past simple and past participle of 
shift
to (cause something or someone to) move or change from one position or direction to another, especially slightly:
examples: She shifted (her weight) uneasily from one foot to the other.
The wind is expected to shift (to the east) tomorrow.

body_content.explanation: (of an idea, opinion, etc.) to change:
examples: Society's attitudes towards women have shifted enormously over the last century.
Media attention has shifted recently onto environmental issues.

body_content.explanation: to move the gears of a vehicle into different positions in order to make it go faster or slower:
examples: In cars that are automatics, you don't have to bother with shifting gears.

body_content.explanation: to leave your home in order to live in a new one; move house
to get rid of something unwanted, or to sell something:
examples: Modern detergents will shift most stains.
The people at the toy shop expect to shift a lot of stock in the run-up to Christmas.
